articles.title: ELECTIVE SURGERY  SCHEDULE
articles.description: solution to predict the number of surgeries for the following days given historical data
articles.contents:
Problem statement
In this case, we aim to predict the number of surgeries given the
scheduled elective surgery records of 4 weeks. All available data can be
summarized with the following 2 graphs






Sesonality
Weekly trend: Doctors prefer Mondays to Fridays.
Autocorrelation
From the case documentation we know that doctors tend to schedule
elective surgery to circumvent public holidays and certain big events.
Which intuitively suggests that the number of surgeries may be
correlated with historical data. From the exhibit 1, we can find a vague
pattern of the daily surgery, which is that a busy day is often
surrounded by several idle days, and a relaxed day is often accompanied
by several busy days. This indicates autoregressive correlations. Given
the stationary demand of elective surgery, we can assume that the daily
surgery follows a stationary trend.
Capturing
volatility(emergency cases)
The trend of emergency cases cannot be predicted as elective
surgeries. But intuitively we know that if it can be captured by the
volatility of the total surgeries. For example, normally the number of
emergency cases occur randomly at a low level. But a fire in the
neighborhood result in a peak of volatility followed by a short flat and
then another peak, since the patients are served and the emergency case
return to its normal low level. This can be modeled with a GARCH
model.
Testing for stationarity
Since the data is too small, I do not perform stationarity checking
using Dickey-Fuller test.
Toy data generation
Given the stationary property of the elective surgery data. I will
generate random noraml data for toying and modeling. Note that affected
by macro factors such as economy demographic changing such as aging and
the shifting of peopleâ€™s attitude towards healthcare, the data cannot be
perfectly stationary without any deterministic trends. But I assume
within one year, these macro factor do not affect the stationarity.

LSTM model
Since we have the data of 28 days elective surgery scheduling. Not
using them will waste these highly informative data. we can try a LSTM
model to do the trick. input shape will be 336x28x1. As ancient
scheduling are likely to change, more recent sheduling are more urgent
and less likely to change.
